note.p: Jehu Amaziah Orr was a representative of Mississippi in the Confederate States Congress during the Civil War.

Born on May 10, 1828, in Anderson County, South Carolina, he moved to Mississippi as a child. He graduated from Erskine College in South Carolina, before attending Princeton University in late 1840s. He left Princeton before graduation due to illness, but returned to earn a Master’s degree there in 1857. Orr became a prominent figure in Mississippi politics as a young man, being appointed as secretary to a Mississippi state convention on slavery in 1849, and later serving as secretary of the Mississippi Senate, a state representation, a district attorney, and then in 1861 being elected a delegate to Mississippi’s secession convention.

Once Mississippi joined the Confederacy, Orr won a seat representing Mississippi at the Confederate Provisional Congress in Montgomery, Alabama. In early 1862, he stepped away from politics to command the Thirty-First Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He led the unit through several battles, until 1864 when he returned to politics and took a seat in the Confederate House of Representatives, which he held until the end of the Civil War.

After the war Orr returned to practicing law. He served as judge of Mississippi’s Sixth Judicial District from 1869 to 1876, and then ran a very successful law firm, serving as the attorney for the Mobile & Ohio Railroad Company. He was married to Cornelia Ewing Van de Graaff and had four children. Late in his life, Orr became an outspoken supporter of women’s voting rights alongside his daughter Pauline Van de Graaff Orr, a notable suffragist. He was among the last surviving members of the Confederate Congress, and was widely praised in the early twentieth century for his more progressive views toward racial and social equality compared to his former Confederate colleagues.
Orr died in on March 9, 1921, at his daughter’s home in New York. He was 92 years old. He is buried in Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Jessica R. Mack, “Jehu A. Orr,” Princeton & Slavery; St. Louis Post-Dispatch, St. Louis, MO, April 24, 1910; The Columbus Dispatch, Columbus, MS, March 13, 1921)

Henry B. Whitfield was a district attorney in Mississippi and editor of the Columbus Press after the Civil War.

Born in Alabama, Whitfield moved to Lowndes County, Mississippi, as a child. His father was James Whitfield, eighteenth governor of Mississippi. Henry Whitfield graduated from the University of Alabama and went into legal practice. He was an officer during the Civil War, reaching the rank of major.

After the war, Whitfield served as a district attorney for the Northern District of Mississippi and edited the Columbus Press in Columbus, Mississippi. He moved to Vicksburg in 1878 and operated a law firm with J. S. Morris. Whitfield died on September 30, 1883. He was married to Mary Montgomery.
(The Vicksburg Herald, Vicksburg, MS, January 12, 1872; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, January 30, 1875; The Vicksburg Post, Vicksburg, MS, October 8, 1883)

Issac N. Osborn was a newspaper editor and Republican official in Louisiana and Mississippi after the Civil War.

His origins are unclear, but Osborn was originally from Indiana. He emerged in the public eye in Mississippi in the late 1860s as the newspaper editor of the Mail in Madison, Louisiana, and a resident of Vicksburg, Mississippi. He was openly Republican and was elected a Mississippi state representative in 1869. In 1872 he took the position as the Mississippi State Librarian, serving in that capacity until around 1875. Osborn then took the role of private secretary to Governor Adelbert Ames in the mid-1870s. During the latter part of the 1870s, Osborn served as inspector of customs and then ran for Mississippi legislature as a Republican in 1880. By the mid-1880s, his name no longer appeared in Mississippi newspapers regarding political or social activities, and his fate is unclear.

(Official Register of the United States, Containing a List of the Officres and Employees in the Civil, Military, and Naval Service, 1879, Vol. 1,, 158; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, December 4, 1869; New Orleans Republican, New Orleans, LA, March 6, 1870; The Mississippi Press, Pascagoula, MS, April 27, 1877, October 29, 1880, and April 29, 1881)

Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.
(Wikipedia)

Located in Clay County, Mississippi, West Point was founded as early as 1844 in what was then Lowndes County. It was incorporated on November 20, 1858. When Colfax County (now Clay County) was established on May 11, 1871, West Point became its county seat and remains so today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 956; Britannica)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: This term refers to the relation, often but not always wives and children, of a person imprisoned in a civilian institution, ranging from jails to penitentiaries.

Widows were classified as women whose legal husband died and they had not legally remarried (Cambridge Dictionary). Due to the bloodshed of the American Civil War, the United States saw a rapid increase in widowhood in the mid-to-late-nineteenth century; one estimate puts the number of widows at over 200,000 (Essential Civil War Curriculum). The Civil War altered antebellum patterns of widowhood by lowering the average age of widows, since many of those who lost their husbands to the war were in their twenties or thirties, and increasing the number of pregnant widows. Since American coverture legally subsumed a woman's identity under her husbands', many widows had no choice but to quickly remarry for social and economic protection.

The Civil War also altered antebellum grieving traditions in that the presence of so many widows, often many within the same community, became more visible due to their numbers. Antebellum social etiquette also stipulated that a woman grieve her husband for roughly two and a half years, while the experience of war often led widows not only to stop mourning but to start rebuilding their lives (and finding other partners) far quicker. In the South, many women inherited large estates and numerous enslaved people upon their husbands' death, becoming solely responsible for maintaining operations and adopting the role of enslaver.

Widows in both the North and South played outsized roles in commemorating the Civil War and deeply impacted the war's popular memory. Women were societally expected to remember their husbands as honorable, infusing that memory into the statuary and literature of the late-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries. Antebellum social and legal practices also ensured that women were generally financially dependent upon their husbands, and widowhood thereby faced many women with poverty. Reform agencies therefore often targeted widows in their charitable work, and the widows themselves sought financial assistance from the federal government by applying for pensions, expanding the American welfare state. While widowhood existed prominently throughout the nineteenth century, the Civil War ultimately increased the number of widows and radically altered their places in American life (Essential Civil War Curriculum).

gloss.p: Pregnancy is defined by the Cambridge Dictionary as "the state of a female with a baby developing inside the womb" (Cambridge Dictionary). Both the philosophies and practices surrounding female pregnancy developed greatly in the nineteenth century United States. The average white woman married at roughly the age of twenty and had an average of seven children over the course of a lifetime.

Families in the early republic valued childbearing for numerous reasons, including having more hands to help sustain the family and produce goods in a time in which many households were self-sufficient. Ideologically, the concept of "republican motherhood" signified that women's role in the nation was to produce and rear children that would become informed and honorable citizens.

However, enslaved women's reproductive capacities were perceived by white enslavers strictly for economic reasons. After the close of the Atlantic slave trade in 1807, enslaved women were raped by their enslavers or forced to "breed" with enslaved men to produce children and thus increase their enslavers' wealth. Women, Black or white, faced numerous health risks during pregnancy and birth, as the mortality rate remained high for all people but particularly birthing mothers due to inadequate medical knowledge and care.

The vast majority of women gave birth surrounded by female midwives and family members. Though some elite white women turned to male physicians to aid in birth, this practice was limited to those who could both afford to pay for a male physician and those who valued university education, remaining largely unpopular until the twentieth century. The rising industrialism of the mid-century U. S., however, slowed birth rates, and the average size of families dropped from seven children to roughly five, as families relied less on making goods in the household and invested more heavily in the advancement of individual children as means of escaping poverty. By mid-century, the knowledge, availability, and use of contraceptives and abortive measures also increased dramatically for women seeking to prevent or terminate pregnancies.

In a nation in which their reproduction often offered the only means of political and civic activity, many women, Black and white, indeed saw contraception and abortion as not only a way of aligning themselves with their own cultural, social, and personal values and desires, but also as an avenue of independent political action and bodily autonomy. The consequent rise in abortions thus led to a reactionary backlash from many white male physicians, politicians, and religious leaders, fearing both the impact of abortion on the nation (due to their ideas of "republican motherhood") and, for enslavers, on their fortunes. The late-nineteenth century therefore saw an increase in anti-abortion laws and restrictions on women's reproductive rights at the same time methods of controlling reproduction expanded. Therefore, as one scholar argues, in the United States, "the nineteenth century was an era of both reproductive revolution and reproductive restriction" (Oxford Research Encyclopedia).

gloss.p: Historically free African Americans included people who were both African American and lived as and/or were legally free before the American Civil War. They may or may not have previously been enslaved. In recognition of African American military service during the Revolutionary War, a number of states moved to gradually abolish slavery leading to a growing body of free African Americans.

Freedom, however, did not mean citizenship, and despite efforts by free Black activists to settle this question and affirm their citizenship, it was largely left to state lawmakers who otherwise failed to settle the question. Consequently, during the Antebellum era, each southern state passed different laws governing the place and rights of free African Americans. Home to the nation's largest free African American community, for example, Baltimore, Maryland registered 25,000 free Black residents by 1850. (Martha S. Jones, Birthright Citizens: A History of Race and Rights in Antebellum America, p. 13)

In another example, South Carolina's Act of 1820 distinguished between those freed before and after 1820, and classified free African Americans as "denizens," which limited citizenship rights by a series of Black Codes. In response to rebellions, numerous states passed legal restrictions that made manumission virtually impossible by the mid-nineteenth century. Loved ones who purchased family members were forced to legally hold them in bondage, leading to a body of people who "were free by practice, but not by law." (Amrita Chakrabarti Myers, Forging Freedom, 3–4, 207)

Unlike South Carolina, Mississippi's judiciary ruled that “free negroes . . . are to be regarded as alien enemies or strangers prohibited, and without the pale of comity, and incapable of acquiring or maintaining property in this State which will be recognized by our courts.” (Heirn v. Bridault, 37 Miss. 209, 224–25, 1859 in Jones, Birthright Citizens, p. 213) The state's strict provisions on manumission led to an extremely small population of free African Americans (773 people by 1860) during the antebellum era ("Free Blacks in Antebellum Mississippi," Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Newly freed African Americans includes people who were enslaved but became free by the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation and/or the Thirteenth Amendment. While neither was comprehensive, the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 freed the enslaved in territories under rebellion, and later the Thirteenth Amendment of 1865 abolished slavery altogether, except when used as a punishment for those who committed a crime and did not apply to Native Nations who practices slavery. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia) In the CWRGM collection, African Americans after December 6, 1865 are classified as historically free or newly freed.

The Cambridge Dictionary defines unemployed people as "people who do not have a job that provides money" (Cambridge Dictionary). Due to revolutions in transportation and industrialization in the nineteenth-century U. S., "the number of unemployed men traveling around the country in search of work increased dramatically" (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol. 2, 26). Unemployment took many forms for diverse reasons. Many who experienced unemployment did so due to nationwide financial depressions or panics, injuries at work, or seasonal layoffs. A large population of unemployed men were migratory workers in the South and West who traveled the country on the nation's emerging railways and performed itinerant labor. Many of these men therefore experienced unemployment temporarily or seasonally. Others experienced long-term unemployment and consequent homelessness, particularly in the nation's rapidly industrializing and crowded cities in the Northeast and Midwest. Men experienced unemployment far more often than women, as many charitable organizations catered exclusively to women, while xenophobia and racism ensured that immigrants and people of color comprised the largest demographic groups to experience unemployment. Aid for the unemployed stemmed almost exclusively from religious or reform-minded charitable organizations, as neither the U. S. government nor many individual states would create a systematic response to unemployment until well into the twentieth century (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol. 2, 26-7).

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

Categories:

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary classifies "a person who lives in the U.S. and is a member of a race of people with dark skin that originally came from Africa" as African American, but both the nineteenth-century and modern constructions are more complex (Cambridge Dictionary). Common nineteenth-century racial categories such as "mulatto" referred to persons with both white and black ancestry, and the experiences of mixed-race persons varied based on complexion, degree of African ancestry, and the region in which they lived. In antebellum cities with large populations of free Blacks, the degree of one's African ancestry could determine what rights one possessed or did not possess, and people with lighter skin tones were often considered to be white; this ended under "one drop rule" during the Jim Crow system.

Like skin tone, the ethnicity implied by the term "African American" is also problematically broad, as "naming people only by the continent of their origin and ignoring their ethnic identity is a consequence of time and space" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 5). The experience of slavery complicated the term by attempting to strip people of their original distinct African ethnic identities such as Ibo or Ndongan, classifying all persons of African descent together under one term, infusing that term with negative connotation, and disregarding the complex and rich linguistic, cultural, and ethnic histories of varied African people. However, many Black Americans have reclaimed the term "African American" and infused it with positive connotations. One scholar argues that "in using the term 'African Americans,' Black Americans accent the part of their heritage that is not American" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 4).

CWRGM — acknowledging the multiplicity of the term's meanings and connotations — includes multiracial and multiethnic people of African descent under the "African Americans" social identifiers subject tag to reflect the diversity of the African American experience and to ensure that the experiences of African Americans of mixed races and ethnicities are discoverable as they are rarely distinguished further in the letters. In the absence of other references, CWRGM also tags racial slurs targeted at African Americans — which were common in nineteenth century documents with white authors — under the "African Americans" tag. CWRGM recognizes the historic and present harm caused by such language and does not condone its use but tags these terms only to ensure the rich history of African Americans are discoverable within the collection.

West Point Miss
January 27th 1875

Whereas One John Hendricks a Col'boy is now Confined in the State Penetentiary Convicted at the last August term of The Circuit Court of Colfax County upon the charge of Grand Larceny or burglary, and sentenced to four years imprisonment in The State Penetentiary. Your petitioners most respectfully petition your Excellency to pardon said John Hendricks of This sentence and restore him to liberty for the reasons To Wit
1st In consideration of his tender years being only about sixteen years.
2nd It is the only offense of the kind he has ever been known to have com-mitted having previously borne a good character
3rd At the time he committed said act his mother was pregnant with child and unable to work and had There on

four little children to support and this said John her only dependance and the extream dullness and tightness of the times made it insufficient for him to obtain work by which he could support his mother and children
4th The Larceny consisted of meat and supplies for his mothers family

5th The act is much to be deplored and under ordinary circumstances would deserve full measure of punis-hment but under the circumstances to alleviate the suffering of his mother's family Your petitioners cincerly believe it was pardonable in one of such tender years and humbly ask & beg That your Excellency extend to him the mercy asked for in cons-ideration of the above reasons and his tender years
6th If your Excellency in his mercy will grant his pardon his mother will remove him out of the limits of the State
F. L. Collins atty
Respectfully Returned

I am amazed that honest men will represent to the Governor that it is "pardonable" to Steal at West Point where I know there is plenty of work bread money for the industrious to earn a living—There were two indictments & two Convictions against this deft. His Sentence was 2 yrs under each Conviction He belonged to that class of young vagabonds who lay around our town & thieve for a living. His Excellency will know the value of Such petitions, when it is represented that he has been guilty of but one offense—

J. A. Orr
Judge
I heartily concur in the statement of Judge Orr above and request that the Petition be denied.

West Point Mississippi
January 27[th] 1875

To His Excellency Adelbert Ames
Gov Miss [gap] Greeting

Whereas one Wesley Westbrooks a col boy is now Confined in the State Peniteneay Convicted at the last August term of the Circuit Court of Colfax County upon the Charge of Grand Larceny or burglary and Sentenced to four years in the imprisonment in the State peniteneary. Your petitioners most Respectfully petition your Excellency to pardon the Said Wesley Westbrooks of this Sentence and Restore him to liberty for the Reasons to wit
1st In consideration of his tender youth being only about twelve years old
2d. It is the only offense of the Kind he has ever been Known to have Committed having previously been a good Carrater
3rd That he was induced to Commit the overt act for which he is now imprisoned by older heads
4th That his mother is a weddowed woman advanced in years with a family of younger children & her Son Wesley has arrived to the age to be of Service to her in the Support
of herself & little Cheldren
6t If your Excellency in his mercy will grant his pardon his mother will Keep a strict Rule on him that he may not be ever Charged of a Similar act So long-as he Remains under her Charge

Jake Bonner
Cornelius MacBride Atty at Law.
